Fields.DialogueText: Can't stand this heat...
It's not that hot out, Saguenay.
It's hot enough. Help me look for an iceberg to throw myself at.
You're being dramatic.
I'm raising concerns. This weather is terrible for getting any kind of work done.

Fields.MenuText: Excuses, excuses.
It's just for this tour, Saguenay. We'll be back above the tropics before you know it.
I have to agree. I'm practically falling asleep at my desk some days.

Fields.DialogueText: I can always summon enough strength for a fight.
Sleeping through the tour will do that.
I know, Capitaine. It's been entertaining.
I've noticed it in the crew as well. We need to light some fires.
I wasn't going to be the one to suggest it. But if you insist...
Entertaining?
... In theory.
Figurative ones.
Of course, Capitaine. Though the occasional slap on the wrist has kept them in line.
If you call tinnitus and concussions slaps on the wrist.
Pourquoi pas? I took a shot. They survived. We communicated better from then on.
You're not seeing the bigger picture.
I personally attended to them in the infirmary, Capitaine. What we break we must also fix.
Ugh. Morganas. Someone ought to teach them that.
@BATTLE
Ice? Why?
It's not a permanent solution, but I thought we could use some of what we had.
So the crew will be stopping every so often to... melt ice under their hats.

Fields.MenuText: We've got ice to spare. Don't you try to use every part of an animal?
You have a better idea?
Only trying to help.

Fields.DialogueText: Very funny, Capitaine. Now, I've never read human bones before...
I do, as a matter of fact.
Your heart's in the right place, Capitaine, but your head's in the clouds.
All right, let's hear your idea.
Water. That's it.
Staying hydrated?
It won't make it any cooler, but it'll ease the fatigue. The heat is just a symptom, Capitaine... uncomfortable as it might be.
We'll have to run your distillers round the clock.
Done. I would have ripped them out myself if I didn't think they could work overtime.
You'd operate on yourself?
Oh, come off it, Capitaine. It doesn't hurt like a shell does. Have you tried tickling yourself lately?
No.
Like that. I can endure anything as long as I know why it's happening.
Morganas, dead ahead!
Well, this should be easy. We know Morganas are rude and violent.
And unlike the weather, you can shoot them.
@BATTLE
Those water stations were a good idea. Thanks again for setting those up.
Quoi? Oh, this? It says "à l'erte."
It means to be on guard, or to be watchful.
Oh, is that your motto?
Oui, they are the words I live by.

Fields.MenuText: My motto is "If you believe, you can achieve!"
I like to live by "Feel the fear and do it anyway."
My motto is very simple: "No day but today."

Fields.DialogueText: Trite, but the spirit is there.
I couldn't agree more. You're not going to get anywhere in life unless you go outside your comfort zone.
I never thought about it that way... You're not guaranteed a tomorrow, so you just have to live for today.
Everyone should have something like that to live by.
Almost a pity that Morganas don't.
Which is exactly why we're going to beat them here today. Action stations!
@BATTLE
Better I do it myself than tie up several crew at a time. It's easy to forget how much hundreds of gallons of water weighs.
Et... voila. There's the last of them.
Say, what's that on your dress?
Capitaine! Come here for a second!
In a moment, Saguenay! We need to prepare for the approaching Morganas!
@BATTLE
I'm famished after that last fight.
As am I. We should fix that.
What's on the menu? Roast beaver?
Don't even joke about that, Capitaine. I've been craving it for weeks.

Fields.MenuText: I'll see if I can get some shipped in.
I didn't think you liked luxuries.
Is it really that good?

Fields.DialogueText: Non, Capitaine, it would not be the same.
Luxury is tolerance of waste. I do not waste these creatures.
Once you've tasted it you can never. Ever. Go back.
I'm sure I could get you a whole pack of them if-
Enough. I'm sorry.
It's all right! I'm not going to push you.
See that you don't.
Here.
What's this?
Part of my apology. I was short with you when we were discussing my tastes.
Beaver?
And the procuring thereof.

Fields.MenuText: My offer stands.
I was more curious about your reaction than anything else.
Have you ever even hunted one?

Fields.DialogueText: It may sit.
I thought that might be the case. The idea just... took me by surprise. I'm not used to surprises.
Some do come close enough to the ship when we're in port. They do so at their own peril.
So you prefer to hunt them yourself.
It's not about preference, Capitaine. It's about courtesy.
It's just an animal.
I made you a tea doll. One of the British Belles sent me some white tea she likes to calm down with.
I appreciate it, Saguenay. What's the occasion?
Ha! You might as well say I'm just a ship.
You're not going to tell me that beavers are sentient.
It depends on what you mean.
I'm going to need the tea for this.
Once things have calmed down a bit, Capitaine. I think the Morganas are finally taking an interest in us.
@BATTLE
So now do you understand? Why I have to be the one who kills the creatures I eat?
I think so. You're the one who knows how to communicate with them.
In a sense. Christians might understand there to be a covenant between me and my quarry.
To use their parts responsibly.
How else are the animal masters supposed to make new ones?

Fields.MenuText: That's a little morbid.
Well, when a mother beaver and a father beaver love each other very much...
I don't entirely understand it, but I respect it.

Fields.DialogueText: Only to those who see death as an ending.
You're incorrigible.
That's all they ask of us.
Fat in the fire, bones in the water, and the hunter must be decorated properly.
Heh. Even the wilderness has uniforms.
Maybe that's our real problem with the warm weather lately. If we just had uniforms that were lighter and breathed better...
I walked right into that one, didn't I?
Hmph. The sooner we're in a cooler climate, the better.
Where's your respect for the environment now?
Intact. That doesn't mean I have to like it.
Teach those Morganas some, will you?
@BATTLE
Does something seem... off, Capitaine?
That's a broad question.
My fishing's really suffered lately.
You make the fish god angry?
We can grapple with your irreverence later. This is worrisome.

Fields.MenuText: Following any fishing superstitions?
Think the Morganas have something to do with it?
Have you tried fishing over the other side of the ship?

Fields.DialogueText: To the letter. I never talk while fishing, and I certainly don't curse.
The Manitou are ever scheming, but it's hard to believe they'd stoop this low.
Every side, Capitaine. I'm coming up with nothing.
Well, we're faster than the fish are. It might be we're just not in one place long enough.
I wish I could believe that. But I follow the precepts of fishing religiously.
Literally.
What?
Missinak.
Indeed. I would know if Missinak were holding them back.
Maybe that's the point, though. There's something you're neglecting.
Or if not me... then one of the crew.
Or the Morganas.
Let's not jump to conclusions. I'll have to think on this. But at least we don't need an excuse to blow them up.
@BATTLE
Keeping a diary?
Capitaine! You scared me!
It's dark. It's hard not to sneak up on someone. Sorry.
No apology necessary, Capitaine. It takes two to be snuck up on. This fish thing must be getting to me more than I thought it would.

Fields.MenuText: We'll get to more favorable waters.
We can get food from elsewhere. You don't  have to catch your own dinner.
There's plenty of fish in the sea.

Fields.DialogueText: I'd like to think we will, Capitaine, but I'm getting discouraged.
I prefer to. And it's not just about food. There's wisdom in fish jaws and fortune in their skin.
And you're scaring them all off.
Is that what you're writing about?
I'm making a list of the crew and what I know of them. I'll find the fishermen among us and interview them.
Take the plank out of your eye first, and all that.
... Hmm.
@BATTLE
Bad joke?
No, I just hadn't thought of it that way. Thank you, Capitaine. When my beliefs overlap, I know I'm on the right track.
Glad to be of service.
Let's maintain this course. We've got Manitou.
These waters are swarming with Manitou! Everyone, get the lead out!
@BATTLE
Join me in my quarters, Capitaine. I've got some mulling to do.

Fields.MenuText: Isn't that something you do alone?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not used to being alone. In fact, I hate it.
Here. Beef and coffee. It's no caribou, but it'll do the trick.

Fields.MenuText: I'd love to, but I've got to get to  the after action report.
Regarding?

Fields.DialogueText: It'll be there when we're done. It's not like I'm getting you drunk.
The mystery's advanced, if only slightly.
Thank you. Say, what did you call the Morganas back there?
Manitou?
That. You've been saying it more lately.
I've been in somewhat of a more spiritual frame of mind. It pretty much means "spirit."
Got it. Figure out what they're up to?
You're assuming they're up to something.
They're always up to something.
I'm not convinced, Capitaine. Evil though they may be, I think there is a place for them. It just might not be in our realm.
What, do you think they're lost or something?
I... I don't know. If they upset the balance of this world, something must rise to correct it. And that something is us.
That sounds like a noble cause to me.
Is it? If the Manitou exist solely to be destroyed... if they are an imbalance and nothing more... what does that make us?
Our friends.
Well, yes, but in the larger context of-
But nothing. One day they'll be gone and you won't be, and the world will be better off for it.
... You take our existence in remarkable stride.
Imagine a world where we didn't talk to our ships. I think that'd be terribly boring, don't you? The new normal's all right by me.
I think I needed to hear that, Capitaine. Thank you.
In a malevolent sense, I take it?
Non. It's more like the Japanese understanding of their kami than like some malevolent ghost. But, perhaps if they were corrupted, or just confused - or out of balance somehow....
Saguenay, are you all right out here?
More than all right. It's so much nicer in the evening when it gets cooler.
The breeze certainly doesn't hurt.
It gives me some quiet time to think. Unless you want to sit with me.

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't want to impose on your time!
Sure.
What if the Morganas show up?

Fields.DialogueText: I insist. I like talking to you.
I saved a spot just for you.
Then we die together.
I would have brought some of that tea if I'd known we'd be relaxing out here.
There's half a pound in the doll I made you. It'll last until next time.
Sometimes I like to look at the stars and wonder what's out there.
You humans are curious sorts. I like that about you.
You don't think of other worlds beyond this one?
Only kidding, Capitaine. And you tell me to lighten up...
Not out there. They're right here with us, Capitaine... parallel to our own.
Tshishtashkamuk, the land of the spirits... the Tshikamu, the bridge which the wolverine crossed to our world long ago...
Heaven?
Certainly an option, if one chooses to leave these worlds when they die. Probably my great-grandmother did.
... You have a great-grandmother?
I have sisters, don't I? Why wouldn't I have other family?
But- that is, I mean- like previous classes of ship, or-
Spot on, Capitaine. Belle genealogy isn't as clean as yours, but my heart tells me His Majesty's S-class destroyers are my mothers' mothers' mothers.
I'm sure they'd be proud of you.
... Yes. Of course.
Saguenay?
Ah. There. Come, Capitaine. Let's give them something to be proud of.
@BATTLE
Frustratingly enough, no. Or happily enough, depending on how you look at these things.
So we've found our culprits.
Non. As long as the remains are returned to the sea, the fish master is content. So it's not us specifically Missinak is angry with.
Morganas, then.
It's always them, Capitaine.
Almost always. Good work, Saguenay. You learned a lot in a short time.
Now we just need to prove ourselves worthy of nature's blessing.
Aren't we already?
In spirit we are. But the animal masters respect action more than words. This isn't something we can simply pray into their ears.
Find anything out from the sailors?
Out of my complement of around 180, less than a dozen reported fishing recently. Of those, they ate what they caught and threw the bones and such overboard.

Fields.MenuText: What do you suggest?
What about God?

Fields.DialogueText: A last resort only.
The same thing I do with any of my prey, of course.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe we're not loud enough.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe indeed. Try whistling your case and see how funny the wind finds it.
I wonder if you might not let me get closer to these next Manitou.
Why on earth would we want to do that?
Some of the American Belles call it counting coup...
@BATTLE
I don't usually find you in the galley. In fact, I don't think I've ever seen you cook.
That's not why I'm here, Capitaine. Look there, in the oven.
Are those... fish bones?
And skins, and every other bit the crew wasn't intending to eat, collected from when the catches started getting scarce. I'm making this offering on their behalf and ours.
I guess a fire on the deck was out of the question.
The spirits respect improvisation in a pinch.

Fields.MenuText: They're certainly flexible.
I thought everyone was already respecting the fish properly.
Acting as intercessor? How very Catholic.

Fields.DialogueText: Times change, Capitaine, and we must change with them. Within reason.
Extraordinary times, extraordinary gestures.
The irony is not lost on me, Capitaine.
There's just one more piece. Thanks again for humouring me in that last fight, Capitaine. It paid off.
A Morgana pennant?
A bit of one that I snatched in the confusion. Never thought I'd stamp out a fire on one of these.
Well, now you get to destroy it properly.
And for a much better cause. Burning this piece of her with the fish should make our intent clear.
Thank goodness. I think I saw it move.
You didn't have to touch it.
Ugh. Manitou? Now, of all times?
Is this going to be okay to-
Leave it. I've already started the fire. It's not going to hurt anything in there.
@BATTLE
Capitaine, Capitaine! Un orage!
Oh no... This isn't another superstition thing, is it?
Capitaine! This is serious!
And with Morganas bearing down on us... Maybe by the time we're done, the clouds will have passed.
@BATTLE
Barely an inconvenience.
Didn't even have to batten anything down. And we even got a rainbow out of it. I'd call that the best of both worlds.
Best of both... Capitaine, come fishing with me.

Fields.MenuText: I'm really not hungry.
Right after a battle? Everyone's got work to do.
Got a message from the spirit world?

Fields.DialogueText: Neither am I, but we'll find someone who is. Come on!
This is work!
Something like that.
All right, let's get to it.
Well, that wasn't so bad as storms go.
Anything bite yet?
No, but- whoa! Saguenay, over here! I've got something big!
Grr... hold on to that rod! This one's - there!
Whoa!
A shark. Well, that's as good an omen as any.
You sure it's not just a fluke?
Maybe if we'd caught a whale.
Har har. So... what now?
We'll have to burn its remains to be sure. In the meantime... fancy some shark fin soup?
Doesn't that cloud look like a shark?
... What? Oh, sure.
What's on your mind, Saguenay? You're looking pensive.
I'm just thinking. About storms, the wind patterns, the cumulus clouds. It's all very strange.
It's got to be exhausting keeping up with all this stuff.
There's meaning in everything we do, Capitaine, even if you don't see it. Our offering pleased the fish master, but who knows what else we've yet to fix?

Fields.MenuText: Humans aren't meant to control fate or even understand it. What's the point?
Doesn't this mean we'll fare better in battle?
Maybe that's what I'm here for. To help you look for those things.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not human. Besides, isn't that the whole reason you tell stories?
It should. That doesn't mean we can let our guard down.
Then I'm happy to show you.
I just wonder what my great-grandmother would say.
Which one was she?
You know her as HMS Somme. Built in 1918 and broken up only a year after I was born.
You just missed her...
Sort of. Belle memories are... strange. Some of us can speak to the sleeping ones, after a fashion. And I can almost see her sometimes, when I dream.
So perhaps you might have spoken in dreams. But neither of you were awake to speak face to face.
And now we never will.
Do you think she might be... that is, assuming Belles work like other people do...
You're asking if she's in the spirit world, Capitaine. I don't know.
Isn't there some way to find out?
This valknut I found could mean any number of things. Its true purpose is lost to history... so I choose to believe all its possibilities are true. I have that privilege.
So the minute I answer your question could be the minute I lose her forever. I cannot risk that.
I'm sorry. I didn't know you felt that strongly about it.
You have nothing to apologize for, Capitaine. Even I believe there are some things I'm better off not knowing.
Well, the things you do know are keeping us afloat.
That they are. And it looks like I must do so once more...
@BATTLE
Capitaine! What is the meaning of this?
Who killed this gull, Captain?
I have no idea! Certainly not one of us.
Grr... you're right. We've been over this with the crew. If it's not one thing it's another...

Fields.MenuText: Well, throw it overboard. That's what you do with other creatures, right?
Why would the Morganas do something so petty?
So what happens now?

Fields.DialogueText: Same master, different procedure. I'm going to need some time and scrap metal.
Perhaps it's them, perhaps it's not. But it's exactly the wrong time for this.
Nothing, if I play my cards right.
I'll be up on one of the smokestacks, Capitaine. I need to build a scaffold for this one.
Why there?
To keep it exposed to the sky and out of the reach of lazy scavengers.
There's still other birds.
Saguenay, what- agh! Get that out of my face!
That's on the head of whoever killed this one. The birds have a right to their own, and the failed hunter will be punished.
Looks like we've got Morganas. Luckily we're around to punish them.
@BATTLE
Arrêtez là, Capitaine! Not one step further!
Saguenay, I was just about to walk the deck. What could possibly-
I suppose there was no keeping it from you.
Are all these gulls-
Dead. Hundreds of them. It looks like our suspicions were correct. Nothing human could have done this.

Fields.MenuText: You'd be surprised.
Morganas... it's sickening.
Did the last one not work?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't doubt that some monster would be capable. But there wasn't the time nor the resources for anyone to do it.
In the extreme.
The animal masters don't deal in terror, Capitaine.
Well, we'd better clean all this off.
Allow me to direct the effort, Capitaine... Merde! Once these Morganas are gone.
@BATTLE
-Oh.
So what happens now?
... It would take quite a lot of scaffolding.
I know this ship is you, but I'm going to have to draw the line at covering it with bones.
Je comprends. They are Missinak's creatures, so they can be returned to the sea.
I thought they were the souls of sailors.
Both of these things can be true, can't they? At least, that's what the Manitou are counting on.
Disrespecting your superstitions and your religion in one stroke. They really are killing two birds with-
Finish that sentence at your own peril.
Oh, hell. I didn't even think.
You can be indelicate, Capitaine, but never malicious. Fortunately, I am capable of the latter.
They made it personal.
They will regret it.
Is there a reason you've sealed off that area of your galley?
A deadly serious one, Capitaine. I'll attend to it once I'm sure we won't be interrupted.
Dare I ask?
After we've dealt with these Manitou. I don't want to put you off your fight. Or your food.
@BATTLE
Ah... so restrictive.
All right, talk. Why did you just phase out of there with a gas mask?
I've stripped the bones of those birds and put them to better use.

Fields.MenuText: Enlighten me.
No. Hell no. I know what you're up to.
In passing. You think it'll work on Morganas?

Fields.DialogueText: It's every ship's nightmare, for it ignites on contact with water. The exact formula has been lost, but approximations can be made.
War brings out the ugliness in us all, Capitaine.
They burn just the way we do, Capitaine.
What's wrong with your normal guns?
They do not speak, Capitaine. I cannot inflect with them. I can only shoot, and shoot, and wait for the Manitou to ask for more.
And the bones?
Saguenay, I hope you're not endangering the crew's safety.
Have you heard of Greek fire, Capitaine?
Our goal is always victory through firepower and maneuvering. I haven't yet tried my hand at pain.
Boiled in a certain substance to make something almost as volatile as the Greeks once used. Don't worry. The ingredients are not inherently toxic.
What substance?
You don't want to know.
I'll accept that with deep suspicion.
Some things are best left to the imagination, remember?
I regret it, but this is a small price to pay. Are the payloads in place?
@BATTLE
That was hell.
We won, didn't we?
Not nearly as easily as you thought we might.
Hélas.

Fields.MenuText: So what did that prove?
Can you tone it down now?
Well, if at first you don't succeed...

Fields.DialogueText: I've been asking myself that.
I'm... yes. I'm going to have to, frustrating as it might be.
I'm not waiting for another dead flock of seabirds.
Are you all right?
I will be, Capitaine. Join me in some tea and let's discuss anything but this.
Every one.
Don't take this the wrong way, Saguenay... but you've been scaring the hell out of me.
Have the crew open with those.
Open fire with special weaponry!
See how the sea burns? Let those Manitou navigate the flames.
I... I think they're doing just that.
Merde. Everyone hold on tight.
You're looking well.
After an interlude.
I'm glad. The crew were steering clear of you, and, well... you just looked sad.
I'm sorry you had to see it, Capitaine. War brings viciousness out in the most beautiful creatures.

Fields.MenuText: That sure is a roundabout way of complimenting yourself.
Do you think the Morganas were once beautiful?
You're my friend. I'm there even when you don't feel friendly.

Fields.DialogueText: I at least earn my vanity, unlike some Manitou I could name. Or some Belles, even.
I... I cannot say. We have never known them at peace.
It is comforting to know, Capitaine. I can be withdrawn, but eventually I must return to the world.
To business, then. Why didn't your trap work?
Fear. Or rather, the lack thereof.
I get what you're arriving at. Greek fire had a reputation almost as wicked as its effects. It caused panic on top of any damage.
And Manitou do not panic. Except Cowardice, of course, and that's only because she's figured out how to use it to her advantage.
So we can't break their morale like we'd like. If we really want to get one over on them, they have to do it to themselves.
Lay a snare and let them walk into it. Hmm... Capitaine, I think I have an idea.
No more boiling bones.
None of that. They want to strike at what we consider sacred? Let them.
Hopefully not these particular ones.
We hunt as usual for now. Later we hunt dirty.
@BATTLE
That... is quite a lot of fabric.
Ça va, Capitaine? Can you sew?
I'm afraid I can't do it to your standards without a few years of continuous practice. I'll leave it to the expert.
Bien. I'm making some of my special tea dolls.
Like that exploding one?
I haven't had to explode it yet. I keep it for emergencies.

Fields.MenuText: How safe is it, really?
What constitutes an emergency?
That little doll could destroy a Morgana?

Fields.DialogueText: It's full of shells. It isn't supposed to be safe.
Imminent sinking. Pray you never see that day.
Maybe, maybe not. But if I'm swallowed by the jaws of defeat, the least I can do is give them something to choke on.
I'll need to sacrifice a lifeboat for this one, with your permission.
I don't like it. Why?
You don't have to. See these uniforms?
Are you dressing them up as medics?
Think of it this way, Capitaine. The Morganas have hit me... hit us... where it hurts. They spit on all that we hold sacred.
What's more sacred on the battlefield than medical personnel?
I considered making little white kittens and puppies from the uniform fabric. Too on the nose?
Maybe a little.
I'll save it for myself then. Maybe a nice beluga...
New mascot?
Hold that thought - I could use a break. And what better way to unwind than a good scrap?
@BATTLE
The stars are still there.
One never knows where they might disappear to, Capitaine.
I don't think the Morganas are a spacefaring species.
Better that we face them now, then. Imagine if they'd attacked a hundred years later...
We'd fight back with your great-granddaughter at our side.
Heh... imagine my descendants being spaceships. I can think of a few American Belles who would love the idea.
You know, speaking of family...
Oui. You've guessed correctly, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: Any closer to hearing her?
She's out there somewhere.
What kind of Belle do you think Somme would be?

Fields.DialogueText: I just might be.
All the gods and spirits I speak to say so.
She was named for a great battle. I imagine she would carry with her each soul that participated. So stern, maybe cold... but unwavering. A little like me.
All the spirits in this world and theirs... you'd think there'd be a way to talk to this one.
There might be. A ritual known to the Montagnais, and therefore to me. But I'd need your assistance, at least in setting it up.
Whatever you need from me, I'm all for it.
You're sure?
I may not understand all of your beliefs, Saguenay, but that doesn't mean I can't respect them. I want to help you contact your great-grandmother however I can.
What are friends for?
Helping each other to succeed at what matters most. Thank you, Capitaine. I'd be honored if you'd assist me.
So what do we do?
All in good time. There's a battle to win first. Then revenge. Then my great-grandmother.
@BATTLE
Saguenay... what you said before... what if you can't-
Then I can't. The Manitou will slip their fingers into whatever cracks they can, exploit any uncertainty. I may as well get to this one first.
Is everything in place?
We've got a motor up and running. All we have to do is set the boat down and send it on its way.
Parfait. Now we just- agh!
All hands to action stations! They've surprised us!
Capitaine, statut.

Fields.MenuText: The decoy boat is intact, thank goodness.
Several injuries, but nothing permanent.
Ears are ringing, but that's about it.

Fields.DialogueText: Dieu merci. If that had gone...
I suppose we must be thankful for that, at least.
Resilient as always. I'd expect nothing less.
This is bad. They're on to us.
Non, Capitaine, that is exactly what they want us to think.
How can you be sure?
It's a feeling. Saguenay, I give you a lot of leeway about your superstitions, but this? The longer we have this boat bomb on board...
See things as I do, Capitaine. You are like the thief who confesses to a crime none have accused him of, simply because he thought he heard an accusation.
Getting nervous because there's something to be nervous about, yes. I understand. But that thing's an enormous salient.
@BATTLE
We have been surprised before. This time is no different. I hate to call it a feeling, but...
Precisely why I stored it astern, near my depth charges. If those are hit, we lose anyway.
Do I make myself clear, Capitaine?
In a sick sort of way.
I'll take it.
Look at it go, Capitaine. From here you can't even tell those are dolls.
Did you ever see yourself hunting with a remote control?
Mm. It's so impersonal.

Fields.MenuText: We can't always be the one to strike the killing blow.
Maybe when this is over I can find another shark for you to hunt.
Wasn't this your idea?

Fields.DialogueText: More's the pity. My knife is getting lonely.
At least buy a girl dinner first.
The best way isn't always the most satisfying way.
Hold it. Is that...
There, on the horizon.
Want the binoculars?
Thank you, Capitaine. I can see.
Looks like they're pulling up beside it, and...
Kaboom.
@BATTLE
How much did you put in those things again?
Enough. All ahead full.
That went even better than I could have anticipated.
Ha! The looks on their faces...
I'd look like that too if someone blew off my stern!
Hahaha! They'll think twice about doing that again.
Bien sûr que non. But no matter. As underhanded as they are... we must dig deeper underneath them.
You think so?
Hopefully not too deep.
Mine were once a peaceful people, Capitaine. We hunted and fished and sometimes we fought, as all people fight.
But others taught us war. The French, the English, the Iroquois... even the Vikings before them, who called us the skraelings. We learned their lessons well.
There's no zealot like the convert, eh?
Nor is there any trick so low that survival stops being worth it. And not unlike a convert... I believe in Hell. I'll see these Manitou there.
Very funny, Capitaine. This is for the ceremony you agreed to.
I agreed to a ceremony?
Whatever it took to contact my great-grandmother, remember?
Ah, I remember now. Is it as... explosive as your last project?
Absolutely not. This is for the shaking tent. It's a ritual hallowed throughout Nitassinan, my homeland.
Tell me about it once we're in safer waters?
The quicker the better.

Fields.MenuText: So what do I do now?
That's it?
What will you say to her if you see her?

Fields.DialogueText: Make sure the tent stays in one place. Other than that, stand there and look pretty. That's all I ask of a friend.
You're my assistant in building this, Capitaine. I honor none but my closest companions with the task.
I'll know when I get there. As my friend and assistant, you will be the first to know.
I'm glad you trust me with this.
I've asked more than enough trust of you, Capitaine. It's the least I can do to return the courtesy.
Should I... avert my eyes?
No need. All the action's inside the tent. I'm going in.
Back at it again with the sewing? Wasn't one boatload enough?
@BATTLE
And... there. That should just about do it. Thank you for helping me set this up.
What's that smell? It's... electric?
Whoa! Saguenay!
Calmez-vous, Capitaine. It's called the shaking tent ceremony for a reason.
So once this is built you'll go in and talk to Somme.
This isn't dangerous, is it?
I'll talk to a Mishtapeu and it will serve as an intermediary between us. I hope.
How do you get more... power?
It can be. Generally the more powerful you are spiritually, the less likely that is.
By hunting, of course. So I should  be fine. I suppose I have the Manitou to thank for that.
About what?
Great-grandma Somme?
I... nothing. The Mishtapeu I spoke to didn't know her.

Fields.MenuText: That particular one?
I'm sorry, Saguenay. I know how much you wanted to talk to her.
Could she be in Heaven, then?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe. I don't know. In any event, that's the one I'm stuck with.
I don't know what I expected.
She's not Innu. It's not impossible.
Well. If it's not meant to be, it's not meant to be. It's not my place to question it.
That doesn't mean you have to like it.
I'm familiar with many things beyond the scope of your senses, Capitaine. I know the names of the creatures and the spirits that watch over them.
I've heard it said that friends are the family you choose. So whatever happens... I choose you. For what that's worth.
More than you know, Capitaine. Thank you.
I was going to split this pot of tea, but if you're otherwise occupied...
That scent... Yerba mate?
Roasted. Figured you'd want a memento, considering that we're leaving the tropics behind.
So what did you find out?
I suppose it was too much to ask that one of them be family.
This land does have its uses, I'll grant you. Mmm...
Saguenay, that's practically boiling!
I know. Care for a reading?
Let me do yours first. Let's see...
Turn it. Ninety degrees... yes.
Is that... a boat?
Friendship. I could have told you that.
Wait, there's more. Almost like... numbers?
G.52... C-Capitaine...
It can't be. Is that...
Somme. Her... her pennant number...
I think I understand your beliefs now. Sometimes it's useful to have more than one place to look.
We've work to do, Capitaine. Ask me when we're finished.
@BATTLE
Well, what did you learn?
Then I won't stop looking. Don't you stop, either.
Wouldn't dream of it.
